value: The Jugol, the wall of the old city

is an ancient city in eastern

) has a population of about 75,000. For centuries, Harar has been a major commercial center, linked by the trade routes with the rest of Ethiopia, the entire Horn of Africa, the Arabian Peninsula, and, through its ports, the outside world.
, the old walled city, was included in the
in 2006 in recognition of its cultural heritage. It is considered

value: the fourth holiest city of Islam

by Sunni Muslims, with 82 mosques, three of which date from the 10th century, and 102 shrines.

value: Shoa Gate, one of several gates into the old city
There is a bus service from
Harar is 54 km by asphalt road from Dire Dawa.

The blue and white minibuses and rental vehicles are available.

value: A mansion that once housed the renowned French poet Arthur Rimbaud. The mansion is now converted to a museum.
The old town is home to ninety-nine mosques and many more shrines, centred on Feres Magala square.
Notable buildings include Medhane Alem Cathedral and the sixteenth century Jamia Mosque.
A long standing tradition of feeding porridge to hyenas one night a year developed in the 1960s into a nightly feeding show for the benefit of tourists.
Handicrafts are available at the market.

There are very few mid-range accommodations.
has a better selection of hotels and restaurants.

value: , from Birr 50 (double), a friendly, a bit out-of-town place, apparently you can watch the hyena from the balcony in the upper floor. Often fully booked.
, from Birr 40 (single), very noisy (disco-cum-brothel), try to get one of the rooms which are the furthest off the disco area.
